awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  Space Debris Awareness Spectrum
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project will develop methods for space-based detection of orbital debris. This technology may decrease risks of collisions in space through real-time, accurate identification and modeling of objects within the respective orbits of the spacecraft. The system will also assist with potential path deviations. With the proposed space-based debris awareness technology, techniques could be employed to prevent future collisions and debris damage. A function of such a system could be for designating objects or debris that require emergency orbital removal due to the threats they pose to critical equipment. Additionally, the proposed systems can be used to detect and avoid kinetic attacks as well as the debris fields generated by them. Further, the proposed onboard sensors may detect a broad range of object characteristics, including size, velocity, composition, origin, and intent. Moreover, the solution will assist in intelligence gathering and identifying parties responsible for collisions. The proposed solution addresses the above-stated concerns by integrating orbital debris awareness platforms on host space vehicles to serve as watchdogs for the geostationary and surrounding orbital altitudes.

This STTR Phase I project proposes to investigate optimal methods for onboard satellite sensor systems to obtain full spherical space awareness for the host satellites, and thereby allow for better predictive and reactive collision avoidance of hostile threats and orbital debris. This technology could advance novel and transformative solutions for eliminating the threat of satellite collisions with orbital debris and enhance space awareness. The technology will improve space operation risk management margins and permit the space industry's safe growth. The proposed work will include research in three (3) key areas: 1) characterizing the debris environment with regard to detection and tracking in the microwave and optical spectrums using the aggregation of data from sensors currently in orbit; 2) identifying and prescribing optimal detection/tracking methods and technologies within the microwave spectrum to permit sensing of sub-centimeter-sized objects; and 3) pinpointing detection/tracking methods and technologies within the optical spectrum to allow sensing of sub-10 cm sized objects.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Major Goals of the Project

The major goals of the NSF STTR Phase 1 project titled "Space Debris Awareness Spectrum Research" are to investigate optimal methods for onboard satellite sensor systems to achieve full spherical space domain awareness, enhance predictive and reactive collision avoidance against hostile threats and orbital debris, and analyze the spectrum noise within the Geosynchronous Orbit (GEO) environment to select suitable radar systems for tracking centimeter-sized objects.

Accomplishments Under These Goals

Major Activities

1. Review of Optical Spectrum Noise Intensity for Space-Based LiDAR:

This activity involved evaluating the noise levels at various wavelengths for space-based LiDAR systems in the GEO environment. The GEO environment presents high levels of radiation, affecting the performance of LiDAR systems. The study examined noise intensity across different wavelengths, including violet, blue, green, red, near-infrared, and infrared.

2. Review of Commercially Available LiDAR Sensor Candidates for Space Applications:

A comprehensive analysis of various commercially available LiDAR sensors was conducted, assessing their resolution, range, sensitivity, and system features. The sensors reviewed include Single-Photon Avalanche Diodes (SPADs), Complementary Metal-Oxide-Semiconductor (CMOS) sensors, Charge-Coupled Devices (CCDs), and Indium Gallium Arsenide (InGaAs) sensors.

Specific Objectives

1. Laser Optimization for Long-Range LiDAR Systems:

The objective was to optimize the laser transmission power required to detect a 1 cm object at a 250 km range. Parameters like reflectivity, beam divergence, receiver sensitivity, and target area were considered. The project recommended using an array of lasers with Coherent Beam Combining (CBC) and Spectral Beam Combining (SBC) techniques for efficiency and reliability.

2. Review of Radio Frequency Spectrum Noise Intensity for Space-Based RADAR:

This task aimed to explore effective methods for onboard RADAR systems to achieve complete spherical space domain awareness in GEO, despite significant radiation levels. The study highlighted the limitations of radar systems below the W band in detecting centimeter-sized objects at long range and proposed optimized design assumptions for a W-band RADAR system.

Significant Results

1. Findings on Optical Noise Intensity:

The study found that shorter wavelengths (UV and blue) are significantly affected by solar UV radiation and cosmic rays, while infrared wavelengths are more influenced by thermal radiation. These findings are crucial for selecting optimal wavelengths to enhance the performance and reliability of optical sensors in harsh radiation environments.

2. Optimization of Radar Systems:

The research provided key insights into designing high-power W-band RADAR systems with significant antenna requirements, emphasizing electronically steered arrays as a viable solution for long-range detection of small debris.

Key Outcomes or Other Achievements

1. Improved Understanding of Noise Levels:

The project successfully mapped the noise intensity across various wavelengths, providing a detailed understanding of how different sources of radiation affect sensor performance.

2. Recommendations for Sensor and System Design:

The project recommended specific wavelengths for LiDAR systems and highlighted the importance of using laser arrays with advanced beam combining techniques. It also provided design assumptions for W-band RADAR systems, facilitating better detection and measurement capabilities.

Opportunities for Training and Professional Development

The project enhanced participants' skills in areas such as noise intensity analysis, laser and radar system design, and beam combining techniques. Additionally, the project fostered collaboration between academia and industry, allowing participants to engage in interdisciplinary research and development.

Dissemination of Results

The results of the project have been disseminated to communities of interest. More specifically, the project team has engaged with industry partners to discuss the practical applications of the research findings and explore potential collaborations for further development.

Plans for the Next Reporting Period

To accomplish the goals set forth, the following activities are planned for the next reporting period:

1. Development of LiDAR Prototypes:

Implement laser arrays using selected wavelengths with lower noise levels. Integrate selected LiDAR sensors with laser arrays for optimal performance.

2. Development of RADAR Prototypes:

Design and develop large-aperture electronically steered arrays tailored for W-band frequencies. Develop efficient power management and cooling systems to address high power requirements. Conduct rigorous testing and validation of radar prototypes to ensure performance under space conditions, including radiation and thermal stress testing.

3. Environmental Testing:

Subject prototypes to environmental testing that simulates space conditions such as radiation, vacuum, and extreme temperatures. Perform detailed performance evaluations to measure the accuracy, reliability, and efficiency of the prototypes. Iterate and optimize the prototypes based on test results to address any identified issues and enhance overall performance.
